title: How to Design Floating Wall Vases

steps.headline: Identify a workspace that will allow you to both drill through the vase and paint the nails.
steps.description: You may need to lay down newsprint to protect surfaces.

steps.headline: Measure the vase to identify a logical place for the hole.
steps.description: The hole needs to be high up enough so you can fill the vase with water, but still ensure the stability of the vase. Measure both the vase’s height and width. From those measurements, identify a central spot for the hole and mark it with your permanent marker.

steps.headline: Insert the diamond drill bit into the drill.
steps.description: Begin to slowly drill the hole. Drill slowly to avoid cracking the glass.

steps.headline: Spray a small amount of water into the drilled area.
steps.description: Brush the dampened drilled glass dust away with a paper towel.

steps.headline: Continue drilling until you have completed the hole.
steps.description: Spray the area again with water and wipe away dampened glass dust with a paper towel.

steps.headline: Paint the nails you plan to use to hang the vase.
steps.description: In order to achieve that “floating” look, you can cover the nails with the same color as your walls for a more blended effect. Allow nails to fully dry before using them.

steps.headline: Identify an area on the wall where you plan to hang the vase.
steps.description: If you are hanging more than one vase, use your tape measure and possibly a level to ensure a symmetrical line.

steps.headline: Mark the area where you will hammer the nail into the wall.
steps.description: Use a pencil to mark the area.

steps.headline: Tap the nail into the wall, on a slight upward angle slant.
Slide the vase onto the nail, making sure the nail fits snugly in the drilled hole.
steps.description: If adding more than one vase, repeat the process to hang them all in position.

steps.headline: Remove the vase from the wall.
steps.description: Fill it with water far enough so it provides water for the plant or flower but not so high that it spills out through the hole. Repeat with remaining vases if you're using more than one.

steps.headline: Add a flower or more.
steps.description: Hang the vase back on the wall. Adjust the flower positioning once the vase is hanging on the wall, for design and aesthetics purposes.

Preparation Identify a workspace that will allow you to both drill through the vase and paint the nails. You may need to lay down newsprint to protect surfaces. Measure the vase to identify a logical place for the hole. The hole needs to be high up enough so you can fill the vase with water, but still ensure the stability of the vase. Measure both the vase’s height and width. From those measurements, identify a central spot for the hole and mark it with your permanent marker. Drilling the Vase Insert the diamond drill bit into the drill. Begin to slowly drill the hole. Drill slowly to avoid cracking the glass. Spray a small amount of water into the drilled area. Brush the dampened drilled glass dust away with a paper towel. Continue drilling until you have completed the hole. Spray the area again with water and wipe away dampened glass dust with a paper towel. Hanging the Vase Paint the nails you plan to use to hang the vase. In order to achieve that “floating” look, you can cover the nails with the same color as your walls for a more blended effect. Allow nails to fully dry before using them. Identify an area on the wall where you plan to hang the vase. If you are hanging more than one vase, use your tape measure and possibly a level to ensure a symmetrical line. Mark the area where you will hammer the nail into the wall. Use a pencil to mark the area. Tap the nail into the wall, on a slight upward angle slant. The vase should lay back toward the wall and not tip forward. Adding the Display Items Remove the vase from the wall. Fill it with water far enough so it provides water for the plant or flower but not so high that it spills out through the hole.
